docs.text: Welcome to Resipedia ¶ For full documentation visit mkdocs.org . Commands ¶ mkdocs new [dir-name] - Create a new project. mkdocs serve - Start the live-reloading docs server. mkdocs build - Build the documentation site. mkdocs help - Print this help message. Project layout ¶ mkdocs.yml # The configuration file. docs/ index.md # The documentation homepage. ... # Other markdown pages, images and other files.

docs.text: 8 Radioactivity ¶ 8.1 Describe radioactivity in terms of: [D] ¶ 8.1.1 Radionuclide decay processes e.g. alpha, beta, positron, gamma, electron capture, internal conversion ¶ 8.1.2 Radionuclide production e.g. natural and artificial radioactivity, [G] ¶ 8.1.3 Exponential radioactive decay e.g. decay constant, half-life (physical, biological, effective), mean life, daughter products, radioactive equilibrium ¶ 8.2 Define the term and give units for: [G] Activity, apparent activity, specific activity, air-kerma rate constant and reference air-kerma rate ¶ Activity is defined as the number of disintegrations per unit time. Usually denoted as A. The SI unit for activity is the becquerel (Bq), defined as one disintegration per second (dps). In radiation therapy, a more common unit of activity is the curie (Ci), defined as: 1 Ci = 3.7 x 1010 Bq Apparent activity (of a brachytherapy source) is defined as the activity of a bare point source of the same nuclide, that produces the same exposure rate at 1 m as the source to be specified. It is determined by dividing the measured exposure rate at 1 m with the exposure rate constant of the unfiltered source at 1 m. It is a measure of the strength of a source, if the source is calibrated in terms of exposure rate at 1 m. Specific activity is the activity per unit mass of a radionuclide. Originally 1 Ci was the decay rate of 1 g of radium, however the actual decay rate of radium has been revised and so the specific activity of radium is slightly less than 1 Ci/g. Air-kerma rate constant Reference air-kerma rate
docs.title: Radonc
8.1.1 Radionuclide decay processes e.g. alpha, beta, positron, gamma, electron capture, internal conversion
8.1.2 Radionuclide production e.g. natural and artificial radioactivity, [G]
8.1.3 Exponential radioactive decay e.g. decay constant, half-life (physical, biological, effective), mean life, daughter products, radioactive equilibrium

docs.text: Activity is defined as the number of disintegrations per unit time. Usually denoted as A. The SI unit for activity is the becquerel (Bq), defined as one disintegration per second (dps). In radiation therapy, a more common unit of activity is the curie (Ci), defined as: 1 Ci = 3.7 x 1010 Bq Apparent activity (of a brachytherapy source) is defined as the activity of a bare point source of the same nuclide, that produces the same exposure rate at 1 m as the source to be specified. It is determined by dividing the measured exposure rate at 1 m with the exposure rate constant of the unfiltered source at 1 m. It is a measure of the strength of a source, if the source is calibrated in terms of exposure rate at 1 m. Specific activity is the activity per unit mass of a radionuclide. Originally 1 Ci was the decay rate of 1 g of radium, however the actual decay rate of radium has been revised and so the specific activity of radium is slightly less than 1 Ci/g. Air-kerma rate constant Reference air-kerma rate
